titleStmt.title: Von Ludwig Wittgenstein an Norman und Leonida Malcolm, 30. 7. 1950
titleStmt.author: Wittgenstein, Ludwig

sourceDesc.p: Original an der Trinity College Library; Kopie im BA. Publiziert (Malcolm Memoir, S. 128f.; WiC, S. 466).

div.p: I was glad to hear that you had a little boy, chiefly because I imagine that that's what you wanted. If all that's wrong with him is that he looks like Norman, I dare say he'll live that down. May everything go smoothly with him & you & Ray!! ‒ The Rockefeller people didn't write to me, & I don't see that they had any reason; I never wrote to them. Nor could I ever see why they should give me a grant ‒ though it would have been nice if they had done. ‒ I'm pretty well, & I'm working but not particularly well. I get tired soon. The climate here, too, is very relaxing. (But I'm not making that responsible.) ‒ As I wrote to you, I planned to go to Norway in August, but I can't go; I may go in Autumn. The man with whom I thought of going has to cram for an exam which he failed in July. So maybe I'll see Bouwsma when he arrives here in August. I have hardly any philosophical discussions. I could see students if I wanted, but I don't want to. I've got all sorts of unclear thoughts in my old head which perhaps will remain there for ever in this unsatisfactory state.
If ever I became clearer again, which is very unlikely, it would be good to have some more talks with you. ‒ Give my good wishes to Doney, if he's still within reach.
Let me hear from you again before long.
P.S. Thanks for the jacket. I'd forgotten all about it & it's mended beautifully!
